verses.text: David built houses for himself in the City of David. He prepared a place for the ark of God and pitched a tent for it.
verses.comment: Faithful rendering; 'houses' refers to buildings, not tents. 'Pitched a tent' is literal.

verses.text: Then David said, 'No one but the Levites may carry the ark of God, for the Lord has chosen them to carry the ark of the Lord and to minister to him forever.'
verses.comment: 'Minister to him' refers to Levitical service duties.

verses.text: And David gathered all Israel together at Jerusalem to bring up the ark of the Lord to its place, which he had prepared for it.
verses.comment: No significant differences; 'bring up' is a literal translation.

verses.text: David assembled the sons of Aaron and the Levites:
verses.comment: The phrase 'sons of Aaron and the Levites' is literal.

verses.text: Of the sons of Kohath, Uriel the chief, with 120 of his relatives;
verses.comment: Names and numbers are preserved.

verses.text: Of the sons of Merari, Asaiah the chief, with 220 of his relatives;
verses.comment: Direct translation of lineage and numbers.

verses.text: Of the sons of Gershom, Joel the chief, with 130 of his relatives;
verses.comment: Same as Hebrew structure.

verses.text: Of the sons of Elizaphan, Shemaiah the chief, with 200 of his relatives;
verses.comment: No significant differences.

verses.text: Of the sons of Hebron, Eliel the chief, with 80 of his relatives;
verses.comment: Literal translation of the name and amount.

verses.text: Of the sons of Uzziel, Amminadab the chief, with 112 of his relatives.
verses.comment: All names and numbers are kept precise.

verses.text: David summoned the priests Zadok and Abiathar and the Levites: Uriel, Asaiah, Joel, Shemaiah, Eliel, and Amminadab.
verses.comment: Names are consistent with the Hebrew.

verses.text: He said to them, 'You are the heads of the fathers’ houses of the Levites. Consecrate yourselves, you and your brothers, so that you may bring up the ark of the Lord, the God of Israel, to the place I have prepared for it.'
verses.comment: Literal translation; 'consecrate' signifies ritual cleansing.

verses.text: 'Because you did not carry it the first time, the Lord our God broke out against us, because we did not seek him according to the rule.'
verses.comment: 'Broke out against us' is a literal rendering.

verses.text: So the priests and the Levites consecrated themselves to bring up the ark of the Lord, the God of Israel.
verses.comment: Direct rendering of the original.

verses.text: And the Levites carried the ark of God on their shoulders, with poles, as Moses had commanded by the word of the Lord.
verses.comment: 'Poles' is a literal object.

verses.text: David told the chiefs of the Levites to appoint their brothers as singers, with instruments of music: harps, lyres, and cymbals, to raise their voices with joy.
verses.comment: 'Harps, lyres, cymbals' are accurate terms for the Hebrew instruments.

verses.text: So the Levites appointed Heman the son of Joel, and from his brothers, Asaph the son of Berechiah, and from the sons of Merari, their brothers, Ethan the son of Kushaiah;
verses.comment: Names are carefully rendered.

verses.text: and with them their relatives of the second order: Zechariah, Ben, Jaaziel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Unni, Eliab, Benaiah, Maaseiah, Mattithiah, Eliphelehu, Mikneiah, and the gatekeepers, Obed-edom and Jeiel.
verses.comment: The term 'second order' matches the Hebrew (less prominent singers).

verses.text: The singers, Heman, Asaph, and Ethan, were to sound the bronze cymbals;
verses.comment: Instrument type (bronze cymbals) kept accurate.

verses.text: Zechariah, Aziel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Unni, Eliab, Maaseiah, and Benaiah were to play harps according to Alamoth;
verses.comment: 'According to Alamoth' is a musical term with uncertain meaning, kept as is.

verses.text: and Mattithiah, Eliphelehu, Mikneiah, Obed-edom, Jeiel, and Azaziah were to lead with lyres according to the Sheminith, to guide the music.
verses.comment: 'Sheminith' is a musical term, left untranslated for accuracy.

verses.text: Kenaniah, chief of the Levites, was in charge of the singing; he instructed in music, because he was skillful.
verses.comment: 'Skillful' reflects Hebrew 'understanding.'

verses.text: Berechiah and Elkanah were doorkeepers for the ark.
verses.comment: No significant change from original.

verses.text: Shebaniah, Josaphat, Nethanel, Amasai, Zechariah, Benaiah, and Eliezer, the priests, were to blow the trumpets before the ark of God. Obed-edom and Jehiah were to be doorkeepers for the ark.
verses.comment: Priests blowing trumpets conveyed as in Hebrew.

verses.text: So David, the elders of Israel, and the commanders of thousands, went to bring up the ark of the covenant of the Lord from the house of Obed-edom with rejoicing.
verses.comment: 'Rejoicing' is a literal term here.

verses.text: And because God helped the Levites who were carrying the ark of the covenant of the Lord, they sacrificed seven bulls and seven rams.
verses.comment: 'Helped' reflects God's provision; sacrifice details are precise.

verses.text: David was clothed with a robe of fine linen, as were all the Levites who carried the ark, the singers, and Kenaniah the leader of the singing. David also wore a linen ephod.
verses.comment: Description of garments is word-for-word.

verses.text: So all Israel brought up the ark of the covenant of the Lord with shouting, with sound of horns and trumpets, and with cymbals, making music with harps and lyres.
verses.comment: All instrument names and terms are literal.

verses.text: As the ark of the covenant of the Lord came to the City of David, Michal the daughter of Saul looked out of the window and saw King David dancing and celebrating; and she despised him in her heart.
verses.comment: 'Despised him in her heart' is word-for-word from the Hebrew.
